fields.description:
The repository browser reports a badge with the number of elements to be committed for each repository.

On previous versions of sorcetree  badges disappears after commits and pushes, but this doesn't occurs with latest verion of sourcetree
fields.summary: The number of modified elements does not update after a commit

fields.description:
Releases don't seem to be using the Tag that you select to give it, it takes the branch name instead.

 

This is quite annoying as we don't always want to call the branch the release version.
fields.summary: Git Flow Tag not working

fields.description:
I am simply trying to log into the sourcetree app that I have just downloaded for the first time. Version Sourcetree_2.6.3a according to the download name.  It will not recognize my email address. If i try to make a new account it tells me that the name is in use by me already but it will not allow to log in and I presume because of the .edu on the end of the email.  It says Please enter and email address where i put in my email. 

 

  !bugfix-email.jpg!

I
fields.summary: Sourcetree not recognizing edu as valid email address

fields.description: As a user, I'd love to be able to do something like hold down option when clicking "Fetch" or "Pull"   to avoid the dialog box, making the fetch or pull operation a single click.
fields.summary: One Click Fetch / Pull

fields.description:
I just downloaded SourceTree after creating a new account on the web. Tried to install it but keep failing during the step "Log in to your Atlassian accoung" using "Use an existing account".

I enter the valid email address i just used to create the new account (email is confirmed) but i get a warning (yellow exclamation) telling me "Please enter a email address" or so.

It just looks like a bug to me. 

I downloaded SourceTree again, and now the UI "Log in to your account" looks ugly with missing styling i would say.

Hope that helps.

Thanks
Daniel
fields.summary: Use an existing account does not work during first installation
Allow @ autocomplete BitBucket usernames in SourceTree commit messages

fields.description: A feature to prevent the user from committing secrets, credentials or passwords to git.  Similar to https://github.com/awslabs/git-secrets
fields.summary: Prevents commits of secrets and credentials into git repositories

fields.description:
Right now, you allow selecting all diffs for ONE hunk.

 

Please allow the selection of ALL diffs for ALL hunks.

 

This way, I can *copy* a file's complete diff from SourceTree and I then can paste this complete diff on one of my text editors, to continue doing *automatic* useful processing that, so far, takes too much of my time.

 

Thanks.

 

Alfredo
fields.summary: Selecting ALL diffs for ALL hunks for a changed file

fields.description: !Screen Shot 2017-09-28 at 1.44.39 PM.png!
fields.summary: Sourcetree Crashes when opening a repo Window

fields.description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
 # Install Little Snitch to easily monitor traffic
 # Load any commit that will load the author's Gravatar image

 

*Expected result:*

The image will load over HTTPS.

 

*Actual result:*

The image is loaded over HTTP which makes it vulnerable to snooping/tampering:

!Screen Shot 2017-09-28 at 2.18.03 PM.png!

Just changing "http://www.gravatar.com" to "https://www.gravatar.com" should work
fields.summary: Use HTTPS for Gravatar images

fields.description: When using SourceTree 2.6.3 and GPGtools 2017.1 (which includes gpg 2.2.0), email addresses are no longer displayed when selecting a key ID.
fields.summary: SourceTree 2.6.3 + GPGtools 2017.1 - No email addresses listed

fields.description:
Somewhere in the later updates, the ability to change an existing password in sourcetree for mercurial accounts seems to have vanished.  I get pull authorization failed as a dialog, and yet no prompt, and the accounts don't seem to have a password field anywhere,  There is no comparable "Authentication" tab in the preferences that matches up with the windows version.  The accounts in the tab on the mac preferences is only remote accounts, nothing that isn't a cloud provider. 

The workaround was to go into the keychain via keychain access and delete the certificate for the repository stored for Sourcetree.  Not exactly an obvious or user-friendly process.
fields.summary: Can't change password within SourceTree anymore
Git Clone Depth
Cloning Large Repo's Progress Indicator - No Feedback

fields.description:
Steps:
 # Launch the app;
 # Keychain dialog appears.

Symptom:

*Controls in the dialog and in repository selector are unavailable for interaction for some time (a minute).*
fields.summary: Blocked interaction because of keychain dialog

fields.description:
I've added my Bitbucket-Account to SourceTree, generated a SSH key-pair during this step and registered the key on the Web.

Cloning, push/pull everything works fine.

After reboot it seems like the key-pair doesn't work anymore (Make sure you have correct access rights and the repository exists).
With ssh-add -L the key isn't listed (before reboot it was).

My config is attached in a screenshot. The Host "Suizi11-Bitbucket" is never used, because the log while e.g. pulling says it will try my default key (id_rsa). So the last Host "*" is used probably.
The Account "Suizi11_Kreisel" only works, because I've renamed the host from Suizi11_Kreisel to bitbucket.org.

Why the original generated Hosts are not used? I think this is a bug.
fields.summary: SourceTree doesn't use generated Host/alias in ssh config

fields.description:
*Summary*

Renaming a local repository in the main app paints the text white, the same as the input field, rendering the text unreadable.

 

*Steps to reproduce*
 # Open Sourcetree local repository list
 # Right-click an item and select "rename" from the context menu
 # Start writing a new name

 

*Expected results*

Text to be of different color than the background of the input field.

 

*Actual results*

Text is white, as is the background
fields.summary: Unreadable text when renaming repo

fields.description: When you're in the middle of a rebase, the key rebase operations (Continue, Abort, Resolve Conflicts) are buried in the Action menu. Since SourceTree can easily know that you're in the middle of a rebase, it should present those operations in the toolbar, or a prominent section of the UI, to lead you through the standard process of resolving conflicts, continue, etc. to finish the rebase workflow.
fields.summary: Rebase workflow should be more obvious

fields.description:
the source tree nothing to commit colors are matching the default color scheme rather than the dark mode color scheme when dark mode is enabled.

!image-2017-09-26-09-40-45-160.png!
fields.summary: SourceTree: Nothing to commit dark mode colors incorrect

fields.description:
Unicode double quotes, “ (U+201C) and ” (U+201D) are a plague for software developers.  They should not be used by default in any editor view where text or data which is meant to be machine consumable. They are small and difficult to see, and are not interpreted as ASCII double quote characters: " (U+0022)

The commit editor began inserting these characters in a recent build.  I strongly advise disabling this developer hostile behavior.
fields.summary: commit editor should provide ascii double quotes by default

fields.description:
Chose use an existing account in setup. Entered my email address and clicked continue. Yellow triangle next to address appears and box saying "Enter email address" is shown. Logs from "~/Library/Logs/Sourcetree" show the message below. Screenshot also attached. Mac OS version is 10.11.6 (15G1611).

 

2017-09-25 22:40:23 +0000 (e) JSON parsing error - The data couldn’t be read because it isn’t in the correct format.

 

 

  !image-2017-09-25-18-45-17-813.png!
fields.summary: Email address not recognized

fields.description: !Screen Shot 2017-09-25 at 10.30.41 AM.png!
fields.summary: Icon and title in repository browser window title bar is blurry on non-retina displays

fields.description:
I've just updated Sourcetree to 2.6 and it can no longer connect to Bitbucket. This happens literally ** *every* time I update Sourcetree and it's driving me completely nuts! 

I have it set up to use ssh keys and it worked just fine in the minutes before the update. Now it asks me to 'connect' button and go through the sign-in. Which makes no difference at all. No error messages onscreen that I can see. Just silent failure.

I'm really not exaggerating when I say this happens every time I update. And I have to confess that I just properly lost my cool when it happened again. Authentication with Bitbucket is the _only_ consistent weak point I have had with Sourcetree for years and it's incredibly frustrating. Otherwise it's a great app and I love it enormously. Can you PLEASE PLEASE PLEASE stop this from happening again and again.

And now, I tried it again to get a screen capture and it says 'too many failed login attempts'.

Man, this is frustrating! I've attached some static screenshots I took earlier. You can see the lack of any kind of errors.
fields.summary: Bitbucket authentication fails on every update

fields.description:
I find it very hard to read on my big monitor whilst coding. I shouldn't have to sacrifice my monitors resolution just to be able to see the text when doing code review.

It would really help me whilst I do my coding and i'm sure it would help others as well.

Please could you integrate this?

I really like using SourceTree but i'm having to go back to terminal due to this as I am able to increase and decrease the font size in the terminal as I see fit.
fields.summary: Ability to resize - zoom in zoom out for changes on the right hand column

fields.description: There should be GitFlow button in the UI like the Windows version
fields.summary: Add support for GitFlow to macOS

fields.description: I can't log in to my Atlassian account on sourcetree because I apparently need to enter a valid email address, but my email address isn't valid.

Thanks,

fields.description:
in sourcetree, in the Atlassian login form, valid emails such as

[c@abc.xyz|mailto:c@abc.xyz]

are not considered as valid.

I cannot connect to my account, and as a consequence cannot use the software
fields.summary: valid email considered unvalid

fields.description:
When selecting a big diff, like a big commit, or range of commits, the UI completely locks until the diff is calculated.

The diff could be calculated asynchronously, and preferably for files that actually fit on the screen (like an endless scroll that loads next files when you hit the bottom of the window).

Or at least it could detect big diff and show you the button to go ahead and display it. Tower app is done this way and UI is much more responsive on large codebases.
fields.summary: Large diffs lock UI
Repository Browser does not update the number of changes after a commit
Opening source slows my entire system down. It's unusable at the moment

fields.description:
As discussed in: [https://community.atlassian.com/t5/Sourcetree-questions/How-do-I-quot-continue-quot-or-quot-abort-quot-an-unshelve/qaq-p/640839?utm_source=atlcomm&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=mentions_answer&utm_content=topic]

If I start an unshelve operation and there are issues that require resolving conflicts, the menu items for "Abort" and "Continue" are not available so it becomes impossible to continue without using the command line. This makes the shelve/unshelve feature somewhat useless.
fields.summary: It is impossible to abort or continue unshelves.

fields.description: We have a lot of branches in one repo. It would make life much easier to find the remote branches if the left hand tree menu had a filter.
fields.summary: Filter for the remotes
SourceTree For Mac is Not as Good as SourceTree For Windows

fields.description: Separate terminal window looks like the last resort when UI is lacking capability. It emphasizes that SourceTree has limited functionality. I would like to suggest how to close this gap between flexibility of git command line tool and Source Tree UI. I would like to suggest integrating terminal window into the main window. Every UI command would "type" in terminal and invoke command. The user would see the log and would be able to intervene into command and add options or type a new command the same way like in separate window for now. It would also allow for learning git for newbie.
fields.summary: Integrated terminal window

Screenshots attached.

fields.description: Rather than needing to go to the Push dialog to do a force push, I'd like the ability to have a checkbox right on the commit dialog (as well as a key command to toggle the checkbox) which could force push changes immediately to the current remote branch.
fields.summary: Add force push checkbox (with key command) to main commit dialog

fields.description: Rather than needing to go to the Push dialog to do a force push, I'd like the ability to have a checkbox right on the commit dialog (as well as a key command to toggle the checkbox) which could force push changes immediately to the current remote branch.

fields.description:
SourceTree versions 2.5.3 and 2.6.3 throw an error when trying to browse Bitbucket Server repos. The error is: operation couldn’t be completed. (SDNetDomain error 7.)

I confirmed this with two separate BitBucket Servers (both running ver. 4.12).

I captured authentication requests and noticed that some SourceTree requests doesn't contain my password in Basic auth header (as seen it sends only base64-encoded username and colon character):

\{noformat}
GET /rest/api/1.0/users/ypetrov/repos?limit=%32%35 HTTP/1.1
Host: devbitbucket.netsertive.local:7990
Connection: keep-alive
Accept: */*
User-Agent: Sourcetree/134 CFNetwork/760.2.6 Darwin/15.3.0 (x86_64)
Accept-Language: en-us
Authorization: Basic eXBldHJvdjo=
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
 

HTTP/1.1 401 Unauthorized
Server: Apache-Coyote/1.1
X-AREQUESTID: @X1HX1Kx121x3405x0
X-ASEN: SEN-4920128
WWW-Authenticate: Basic realm="Atlassian Bitbucket"
Content-Type: application/json;charset=UTF-8
Content-Length: 197
Date: Wed, 20 Sep 2017 06:01:12 GMT
\{"errors":[\{"context":null,"message":"Authentication failed. Please check your credentials and try again.","exceptionName":"com.atlassian.bitbucket.auth.IncorrectPasswordAuthenticationException"}]}
\{noformat}
fields.summary: Sourcetree for Mac sends empty password to Bitbucket Server REST API

After entering the search term

Pressing Tab skips the search type and goes straight to the From field.

 

This means if I'm searching for a commit hash, I have to switch back to use the mouse to select 'Commit SHA'.

Include the select in the list of tabbable elements so that entering tab at the Search Term field causes focus to jump to the Search Type field

Shortcut key for repository browser window opens the file dialog

fields.description:
When you select multiple files in the unstagged area, generating the diff can take a long(er) time, especially with images. The generation of the diff blocks the main UI thread and causing the beach ball to become visible.

 

I would suggest that the generation of these diffs should be done on a background thread.
fields.summary: Diff should be generated on a background thread

fields.description:
I cloned a repo this morning and started seeing a dialog popping for each submodules asking for credentials that had an incomplete url: https://

This popped each time I hit SKIP on that dialog.

I ended up using `git submodule update --init --recursive` on the command line instead and noticed that I was asked for the passphrase for SSH. I suspect that this is what is causing source tree to show the dialog.
fields.summary: Cloning a repo with submodules will cause a dialog to pop for credential with a https:// empty url

fields.description:
I've got a *lot* of "issue-xxxx" / "xxxx-description" type branches
should would be nice if they were sorted numerically/naturally
fields.summary: Branch Tree / List should be natural sorted

fields.description:
Using git fork terminology for origin and upstream,

1) checkout an upstream branch, then switch off that branch

2) right-click to delete the branch from step 1 which is listed in my local branches

3) in the dialog, check the option to force delete, but not the option to "Delete remote branch [upstream/...]"

 

The upstream branch gets deleted.
fields.summary: Branch delete: not checking 'Delete remote branch [upstream/...]' still deletes it

fields.description:
When using SourceTree to clone a git repository, SourceTree displays a dialog with a full progress bar and a few lines of text, but then no feedback on the progress (or lack thereof) of the operation.

Sample text:
{code}git -c filter.lfs.smudge= -c filter.lfs.required=false -c diff.mnemonicprefix=false -c core.quotepath=false -c credential.helper=sourcetree clone --branch master <source URI> <checkout path>
Cloning into '<checkout path>'...
warning: templates not found /usr/local/git/share/git-core/templates
<no feedback>{code}

I just had a co-worker, who normally uses another source control tool, make a fresh clone of the repository. We started the clone, then sat there staring at the dialog, unsure if there was a problem contacting the server (maybe it failed to display the error?), if the operation was in progress (how far? or did it start and then fail?), if the operation had succeeded, or what. We did look in the target directory, but found no files, not even a .git directory, so we thought something had gone wrong and tried it again. The second time, we let it sit for several minutes and it did complete.

The expected behavior would be to have _some_ sort of progress indicator. The best would be to have a single progress bar that fills up once. (The dialog currently contains a progress bar, but it fills up immediately, long before the operation completes.) IIRC git can tell you the size of the repo and can report the amount of data transferred, so that could be part of the progress, and then any post-transfer work would fill it up the rest of the way. If that’s too hard, it would be useful to at least have a text field that gets updated with the current step of the operation (i.e. “git: downloading hunk 2349cb…”). The changing text would give the user visual feedback that something is still happening. If you can’t do those, an indefinite progress indicator would be better than nothing. In any case, the indicator should be tied to the activity of the operation.

The key phrase there is “tied to the activity”—I don’t want an indicator that updates completely independently of the operation. In other words, if the operation doesn’t make progress (the DNS lookup is taking several seconds, git is connected to the server but data transfer is super-slow, etc.), the indicator should stop updating. If you spawn off git as another process and that process crashes, SourceTree should recognize that and display an error message. It should be clear that an operation is still active so that the user knows  that it hasn’t ended, either cleanly or due to an error.
fields.summary: Cloning a repository gives no feedback on progress

fields.description: select branch in UI, then choosing Repository > Interactive Rebase - the process does not seem to work - doesn't show the commit list, never seems to finish properly even when there are no conflicts
fields.summary: Interactive Rebase

fields.description: After upgrading to SourceTree 2.6.3 for Mac, the Vertical scrollbar no longer appears in the repository browser window.  This makes it annoying to use as I can only use my mouse wheel to navigate inside the window.

fields.description:
Git status shows branch up to date and nothing to commit.

I got to "file status", enter a filename in the search box, right-click on the found php file, click "Blame Selected".

The output of the command seems to be garbled. Only the first line is correct (that is why I blurred out my name). Please see attached screenshot.

I have a tried a couple of other files, and the output seems to be correct for the other files.
 Git command line output for this file also seems abnormal. Here is a sample of running the command in the osx terminal:
{code:java}
$ git blame web/app.php
00000000 (Not Committed Yet 2017-09-12 15:05:29 +0300 1) <?php^M// mysqli polyfill^Minclude_once('lib/mysql_mysqli.inc.php');^M^Minclude_once('lib/funcs.php');^Minclude_once('lib/errorHandling.class.php');^M!isset($_SERVER['SERVER_ADDR']) and $production = true;^M^M!isset($production) and $production = ( ^M    (substr($_SERVER['SERVER_ADDR'],0,7)!='192.168')^M      and (substr($_SERVER['SERVER_ADDR'],0,9)!='127.0.0.1') ^M);^M^Mif ($production) {^M     error_reporting(false);^M       // $adapter = dbConnect("HOST", "USERNAME", "PASS", "DATABASE");^M} else {^M    // testing server^M     if(!isset($config['error_reporting'])) {^M              error_reporting(E_ALL ^ E_DEPRECATED ^ E_STRICT);^M     } else {^M              error_reporting($config['error_reporting()']);^M        }^M     ini_set('display_errors', 1);^M // error_reporting(false);^M}^M^Mif((iev{code}
"|head -5" barely prints a single line. Something to do with line endings?
{code:java}
$ git blame web/app.php |head -5
?>rr = new ErrorHandling();lang'] = "fr";'])) {g'];ass.php"); Avoids zombie connections.
$
{code}
 This is what normal blame output looks like:
{code:java}
$ git blame web/index.php |head -5
^84ed02e index.php     (Rolf         2012-11-29 11:43:39 +0100   1) <?
^84ed02e index.php     (Rolf         2012-11-29 11:43:39 +0100   2)
^84ed02e index.php     (Rolf         2012-11-29 11:43:39 +0100   3) require_once ("app.php");
^84ed02e index.php     (Rolf         2012-11-29 11:43:39 +0100   4)
afab12b9 index.php     (Rolf         2013-10-17 12:48:10 +0300   5) gets("d"); // page, dataset{code}
 

I am also attaching the php file that is causing garbled output (app.php). I have just removed a couple of lines that contain sensitive information.

If you need any more information or for me to complete any steps, please let me know.
fields.summary: Blame output garbled

The badge that reflects the current branch the repository is on, does not update when changing branches. The file status badge also doesn't update to reflect the actual number of files in 'File status'.

It does change when I focus on another application.
In the attachment, I do that by switching between desktops. On the other desktop Finder is active.

 

I'm running Mac Sierra version 10.12.6.

Crash while in background; no SourceTree code in backtrace

fields.description:
In the Welcome wizard, during step 3: Atlassian account, I clicked on "Use an existing account" where I can either use Google authentication or type my email. I entered my email directly (which is a gmail address) but received the error message "Please enter an email address" whether I press Enter or click on Continue.

Using the Google authentication solved my issue, and is most likely the intended method for Gmail users. However, it would be more user friendly to either show a dedicated error message such as "Please use Google authentication for Gmail accounts" or better, to redirect the user to Google authentication when a Gmail address is detected. Finally, some users may actually want to input their Atlassian password and not their Google password, in which case we should let them use the email method although they have a Gmail address.

I don't know if non Gmail users had the same issue with the email method. Please comment.

I mark the bug severity as minor because there is an alternative in this case, but if the bug also occurs for non Gmail users, then they are stuck in the install wizard.
fields.summary: "Please enter an email" error despite entering valid Gmail address
I AM SOWRAV HALDAR

fields.description:
When I have signed in using Oauth under accounts. 

It doesn't seem to use the SSH key generated to push.  

 

Steps to replicate
 # Sign into Bitbucket using oauth

!image-2017-09-04-22-42-19-644.png!

2. Click copy to clipboard and try paste it into bitbucket-> settings -> SSH keys -and it will validate in Bitbucket that its already been added

!image-2017-09-04-22-43-14-674.png!

3. You will still get permission denied when you attempt to push to a private repos which you have access for. Even if you try use the Bitbucket setting for downloading from sourcetree - it will still say that the repos url is invalid - as you don't have access 

!image-2017-09-04-22-41-27-006.png!  

!image-2017-09-04-22-40-48-502.png!

The reason.. is that Source tree is using the wrong key to connect..

 

If I try use command line - it works correctly

fields.description:
Every push generates the authentication warning below but the push works. However, after several times, it will stop working with an error about too many login attempts and I have to re-enter my Bitbucket credentials. I do not have 2factor on.

This started happening with a Sourcetree upgrade that took place within the last 2-3 weeks. Only happens on Mac.

 

Pushing to https://jdoe@bitbucket.org/companyname/repo.git

remote: Invalid username or password. If you log in via a third party service you must ensure you have an account password set in your account profile.

fatal: Authentication failed for 'https://jdoe@bitbucket.org/companyname/repo.git/'

Pushing to https://jdoe@bitbucket.org/companyname/repo.git

POST git-receive-pack (826 bytes)

remote:

remote: Create pull request for staging:        

remote:   https://bitbucket.org/companyname/repo/pull-requests/new?source=staging&t=1        

remote:

To https://bitbucket.org/companyname/repo.git

   c83727a..b916b81  staging -> staging

updating local tracking ref 'refs/remotes/origin/staging'

Completed successfully
fields.summary: Invalid username or password and push succeeds for a couple times and then fails, requiring re-auth with Bitbucket

fields.description: "Show in Finder" text couldn't show all when using Chinese
fields.summary: Nothing to commit Text UI layout issue

fields.description:
Collapse a folder of repos and expand it and the repo icons are 'smashed' together.

 

(Screenshot attached)
fields.summary: UI Defect when expanding folders of repos

fields.description:
It seems that the date column in commits table is not localized properly as seen on attached screenshot.

!Screen Shot 2017-08-29 at 13.27.44.jpg!
fields.summary: Commit date column doesn't use localized date and time

fields.description:
After updating to 2.6.1, I noticed that the icons in the repository browser render poorly when collapsing/expanding folders. They float above everything and don't disappear until I scroll the window.

 [^goofy_icons.m4v] 

I've tried with both dark & light themes and restarting the app & my computer don't make a difference. It's very distracting and makes using the app unpleasant.
fields.summary: Repository icons render oddly

fields.description: Focus the Commit message field via right-click and ST will let you type (after dismissing the context menu) but doesn't really see it as focused (field is not expanded with the Commit Options, a Cancel button, etc.) and any text typed is lost when you blur and left-click the field.
fields.summary: Right-click to focus Commit message doesn't really focus

fields.description: When opening and closing lists, the blue images start to overlap. Also have a look on the screenshot I took.
fields.summary: Overlapping images

fields.description: Repo icon overlay when clicking group name, shown as pic attached.
fields.summary: Repo icon overlay when clicking group name

fields.description:
A commit may add or modify many many files with a lot of diffs.
When click on a commit from History or Search view, bottom right window will try to load all the diffs of this commit. (tree view, defaults select the top folder)
This make SourceTree not response for a really long time.
 
See demo video in attachment for more detail.
Try the demo project to experience for yourself.
fields.summary: Large commit diff view load slow block main thread, better manual trigger load
Reverse commit command doesn't work for merge commits

fields.description:
If you delete an empty Repository Group, it gives a warning:

"Are you sure you want to remove the following nodes, and all of their children?"

First off it's inaccurate because there are no children, and second it seems a little unnecessary because it made me think I was doing something riskier than what it actually was :)

Maybe the confirmation could be skipped if there are no children?
fields.summary: Unnecessary confirmation when deleting empty bookmark group

fields.description:
When using repository groups and expanding and collapsing groups, repository icons start overlapping and diverging.

 

!sourcetree.png!
fields.summary: Repository Icon visual glitch

fields.description:
After doing a commit the view changes to show History. If a user has more file changes to commit he has to press the Commit button again.

This break the commit process of the user by adding an unnecessary step.

Remaining in the commit mode (at least if there are more files to commit) is the desired behavior.
fields.summary: Remain in commit mode if there are more files to commit

fields.description:
# Click on the Project Name
 # Click on the search (Filter repositories) 

!image-2017-08-24-12-59-41-765.png!
fields.summary: Dark Theme Bug when selected project, then click on search, the color contrast not able to see text

fields.description:
As described by Atlassian itself, `git push --force` can be dangerous; there is a safer `--force-with-lease` flag, though:

[https://developer.atlassian.com/blog/2015/04/force-with-lease/]

This requires you to have the current state of the branch you're pushing "with force" to fetched or the push will be rejected.

For some time now I've been pushing with `--force-with-lease` when rebasing my feature branches and I have to do it from the command line.

I'd like for SourceTree to be able to enforce `--force-with-lease` and disallow `-force` so that I always have to fetch if the data I see on the screen is out of date *before* pushing.

I've originally noticed the issue reported for the Windows version of SourceTree: SRCTREEWIN-3045
fields.summary: Support git push --force-with-lease

fields.description:
SourceTree should support TouchBar on MacBook Pros by exposing frequently used or new simpler commands that are not accessible using key shortcuts.

Examples of existing commands that could be in TouchBar:
 * Stash
 * Show In Finder
 * Terminal
 * Options to Resolve Conflicts when a file is selected (currently these options are deep in contextual menu)
 * Log and Blame selected files

Examples of new simplified commands for quick workflows:
 * Quick Pull (no dialog, reuse last settings)
 * Quick Push (no dialog, reuse last settings)

TouchBar could also show brief progress of commands, instead of modal sheet that appears everytime something is in progress.
fields.summary: TouchBar support

fields.description:
SourceTree freezes a lot and it becomes unusable for 10-15 seconds until it recovers (if it does). I have a repository with a submodule, freezing usually happens when opening the submodule in history view. 

I am not modifying lots of files or using the program in any intensive way, that's why I don't understand why so much freezing.
fields.summary: SourceTree freezes very often (few repositories but extensive CPU usage)

fields.description:
Steps to reproduce:
# Use SourceTree for some time - open & close repository details, commit, merge etc.
# Try closing some repository detail window. Does not matter whether using Cmd+W or clicking the top-left red close button.
# The window takes several seconds to close, appears stuck in the meantime (not animating). The closing seems to get worse the longer you use SourceTree.

After restarting SourceTree, the problem disappears - and then starts appearing again after a few actions with it.

An important observation is that this problem started with the version 2.6.1 - it was not present in any of the previous versions as far as I can tell (certainly not in 2.5.x - would have noticed).
fields.summary: Repository window takes long to close

fields.description:
How about making it possible to override what the "Log Selected" feature runs as a command under-the-hood in SourceTree? By configuring it somewhere in the preferences users would get a lot of flexibility.

My motivation is that I would like my sourcetree's "Log Selected" feature to use the `--follow` flag and even list the history before any file renames occured.
fields.summary: Make "Log Selected" configurable in preferences

fields.description: When working with multiple git repositories within 1 window, tabs appear at the top of the window to switch to another repo. It would be nice if the file status badge (changed files count) is also visible in those tabs to check what other repo's have uncommitted changes.
fields.summary: Show file status badge also in SourceTree tabs

fields.description: Since the latest SourceTree update the compact view icons have been broken. They have a rectangular rotated shape that looks out of place (see the first screenshot). During folding & unfolding of project groups the icons jump and are shown in completely incorrect places (the second screenshot was taken during an animation).
fields.summary: Compact view icons broken
We've encountered a problem. Please try again in a few minutes

fields.description:
I have a list of git repositories. I have them separated into different repository groups. When I expand or collapse the groups, the icons on the left get all out of whack. If I background the app and come back to it, they are fixed. 

See the attached screenshot. I've cut out group/repo names to protect the innocent.
fields.summary: Expanding/Collapsing Repository Groups Leads to Visual Glitches

fields.description: When editing a commit message, pressing Cmd-Up does not move the cursor to the start of the document, but instead shows a history of previous commit messages. While history is a useful function, it should not override a standard system shortcut — Cmd-Up means "move to start of document" in _every_ Mac app. Could the keyboard shortcut for this be changed to something non-conflicting?
fields.summary: Cmd-Up does not move cursor to start of document when editing commit messages

fields.description:
Currently there are no efficient workflows for working with multiple repositories. I have to open the Repository Browser window, choose the repository I want to work with, find the Repository Browser window, close it, do actions on the selected repository, close it's window then invoke a menu command or press on the Dock icon again to reopen the Browser.

I think this should be avoided if you changed a little bit the way this works. I think you should think only in repository windows instead of the Repository Browser + repository windows. I think Safari is a perfect example: you can open as many windows as you want, they open with a list of bookmarks (in Source Tree: saved repositories), the user selects one of them or adds a new one and uses the same window to manipulate the selected repository. After he or she finishes, closes the window. Much cleaner workflow, and lacks the need of opening and closing the Repository Browser manually.

To be clear: I think you should integrate the Repository Browser's contents into the main (repository) windows, and let the user select some save repo then change the window content to reflect the repo window.
fields.summary: Integrate Repository Browser into main window

fields.description: SourceTree should take benefit of the system Tab support. Each tab could have the same interface as the repository viewer windows do currently.
fields.summary: System tab bar support

fields.description:
Sorting options would be extremely helpful for large project.   There are a number of tickets in the windows version tracker, but I don't see any in the mac version tracker.

Side bar:   remotes, branches etc.

Repositories config - either sort alphabetically or just manually drag and drop to a manual order, which would affect push/pull select boxes.   That way you could put the most used ones at the top of the list, and dangerous (production) at the bottom of the list.
fields.summary: Sorting options
Repository logo overlaps section header in repositories list

fields.description:
I would like to select multiple discrete commits in History tab, and use context menu(right menu)'s "Reverse Commit..." to revert them all, I'd also like it to show the new commit as a single one instead of multiple commits.

Currently SourceTree shows "Reverse Commit..." when I select a single commit, but grays it out when I select multiple commits.

Git supports it, and I think it's not that hard to implement. And also, please consider adding an option box to highlight commits made by others. I need this because I work in a cooperative, and often need to cleanup our master branch from others' old commit in order to do a "Emergency Rollback" or such.
fields.summary: Revert multiple discrete commits

fields.description:
Copy appears to do nothing if there is one or more commit selected.

I'd like it to copy information about each commit, one per line, tab-delimited. The information should include the description, commit-id, date and author.
fields.summary: Copy all selected commits' information into clipboard

fields.description: I have dozens of repros. I do a weekly accounting of commits in all repros over the last week. It sure would help if I could sort my repro list by most recent commits. Then I could work through them in reverse-updated order and ignore all the repros that weren't updated in the last week.
fields.summary: repository browser: sort repositories by most recent commit

fields.description: After cloning a repository from github and committing a change, I edited the user info in advanced repository settings to turn off the global user settings (which uses my work email account), and set my email address to my private email account (which corresponds to my github login). When I try to create a pull request, it incorrectly tries to use the global user info for the request instead of the user info I specified for the repository.   This renders the "create pull request" feature unusable for this case.
fields.summary: Create pull request doesn't respect user information

fields.description:
upgraded to latest macOS and SourceTree on same day. Now experiencing visual glitches with duplicate/overlaying repository icons in the Repository Browser when clicking the widget to expand a folder grouping of repos. Happens on scaled 4K and non-retina display.

Quitting and re-launching SourceTree any ensuring any open windows are on my 4K display seems to fix it.
fields.summary: Visual glitches in Repository Browser when expanding/collapsing folder groups
